How we measure 'reads'
A 'read' is counted each time someone views a publication summary (such as the title, abstract, and list of authors), clicks on a figure, or views or downloads the full-text. Learn more

Introduction
David Salazar-Valenzuela works at BioCamb (Centro de Investigación de la Biodiversidad y Cambio Climático), Universidad Tecnológica Indoamérica.
Skills and Expertise

Conservation Biology
Animal Ecology
Natural History
Ecology and Evolution

Taxonomy
Biodiversity

Ecology

  • Ricardo Palma Patiño
  • David Salazar-Valenzuela
  • Evencio Joel Medina Villamizar
  • [...]
  • José Rafael De Almeida
Bothrops atrox is the most clinically relevant snake species within the Amazon region, which includes Ecuadorian territories. It comprises a large distribution, which could contribute to the genetic and venomic variation identified in the species. The high variability and protein isoform diversity of its venom are of medical interest, since it c...

Venom variation in Bothrops asper lineages from North-Western South America
Article
  • Aug 2020
  • Diana Mora-Obando
  • David Salazar-Valenzuela
  • Pla Davinia
  • [...]
  • Juan J Calvete
Bothrops asper is a venomous pitviper that is widely distributed and of clinical importance in Mesoamerica and northern South America, where it is responsible for 50–80% of all envenomations by Viperidae species. Previous work suggests that B. asper has a complex phylogeographic structure, with the existence of multiple evolutionarily distinct line...

  • José Rafael De Almeida
In Ecuadorian Amazon, Bothrops atrox is the main snake associated with ophidic accidents. The only approved treatment for snakebite envenomation are antivenoms and their efficiency depends on the reference venom used in their production. It is important to mention that B. atrox is a species with wide geographic distribution, which can generate diff...

  • [...]
  • Paola A. Carrasco
We describe a new species of montane pitviper of the genus Bothrops from the Cordillera Oriental of the Central Andes, distributed from southern Peru to central Bolivia. The new species can be distinguished from its congeners by the characteristic combination of a dorsal body color pattern consisting of triangular or subtriangular dark brown dorsal...

Article
Full-text available
  • May 2019
  • Omar Torres-Carvajal
  • Gustavo Pazmiño-Otamendi
  • David Salazar-Valenzuela
With 477 species of non-avian reptiles within an area of 283,561 km 2 , Ecuador has the highest density of reptile species richness among megadiverse countries in the world. This richness is represented by 35 species of turtles, five crocodilians, and 437 squamates including three amphisbaenians, 197 lizards, and 237 snakes. Of these, 45 species ar...

Systematics of South American snail-eating snakes (Serpentes, Dipsadini), with the description of five new species from Ecuador and Peru
Article
Full-text available

  • Alejandro Arteaga
  • David Salazar-Valenzuela
  • Konrad Mebert
  • [...]
  • Omar Torres-Carvajal
A molecular phylogeny of the Neotropical snail-eating snakes (tribe Dipsadini) is presented including 43 (24 for the first time) of the 77 species, sampled for both nuclear and mitochondrial genes. Morphological and phylogenetic support was found for four new species of Dipsas and one of Sibon , which are described here based on their unique combin...

We describe a new species of Trilepida Hedges 2011 from cloud forests of the extreme northern Ecuadorian Andes, Carchi province. Projects

Project (1)
Reptiles of Ecuador: a free and resource-rich online portal, with dynamic checklists and photographic guides
Project
The high rate of species descriptions during recent decades, along with frequent taxonomic changes, has prevented printed checklists and books from maintaining a reasonably updated record of the species of reptiles from Ecuador. Here we present Reptiles del Ecuador (http://bioweb.bio/faunaweb/reptiliaweb), a free, resource-rich online portal with updated information on Ecuadorian reptiles. This interactive portal includes encyclopedic information on all species, multimedia presentations, distribution maps, habitat suitability models, and dynamic PDF guides.
View
